solution_line_template: If Marcus creates {day1_paintings} paintings on the first day, then he can paint {day1_paintings} paintings * {multiplier} = <<{day1_paintings}*{multiplier}={day2_paintings}>>{day2_paintings} paintings on the 2nd day.
So he paints {day2_paintings} paintings * {multiplier} = <<{day2_paintings}*{multiplier}={day3_paintings}>>{day3_paintings} paintings on the 3rd day.
He then paints {day3_paintings} paintings * {multiplier} = <<{day3_paintings}*{multiplier}={day4_paintings}>>{day4_paintings} paintings on the 4th day.
And finally paints {day4_paintings} paintings * {multiplier} = <<{day4_paintings}*{multiplier}={day5_paintings}>>{day5_paintings} paintings on the 5th day.

Marcus therefore has painted a total of {day1_paintings} + {day2_paintings} + {day3_paintings} + {day4_paintings} + {day5_paintings} = <<{day1_paintings}+{day2_paintings}+{day3_paintings}+{day4_paintings}+{day5_paintings}={total_paintings}>>{total_paintings} paintings.
